title: Mum finally weans daughter off turkey dinosaurs with genius hack
text:
Scarlett-Mai, 5, with trying new food chart (Picture: @youngmumsdiaries/Caters)

A mum has come up with a genius hack to ween her daughter off turkey dinosaurs and waffles and to get her eating healthy meals.

Karis Turner, 23, says she was desperate to ensure her five-year-old daughter Scarlett-Mai ate all her greens, so worked with her school to pick healthy meals.

The year one pupil is awarded with stickers and medals on a weekly basis, to get her to break her unhealthy eating habits.

Karis from Heywood, Manchester, has now got Scarlett-Mai eating fish cakes and Quorn cottage pie.

She said: ‘Scarlett-Mai wasn’t getting the nutrients she needs as she would refuse to eat anything but classic child dinners such as waffles and dinosaurs.

‘I thought if I make trying new foods fun and a competition, she will be encouraged to change her ways.

‘I purchased some plastic medals, trophies and printed off certificates and bought some happy and sad stickers to show what she liked and disliked.

Mum Karis Turner, 23, says she thought of making new foods fun and a competition (Picture: @youngmumsdiaries / Caters) ‘But so far, we have only had to use the smiley stickers as she has loved everything, and she can’t believe it.’

Karis rewards Scarlett-Mai with a medal at the end of the week if she eats all her dinners and also allows her to choose an activity of her choice like baking.

The inspiration behind the idea came when Karis introduced a reading book chart and noticed Scarlett-Mai’s enthusiasm towards books had changed.

She picks five books a week to read and is rewarded with stickers – Karis says even her teachers have noticed the improvement.

Scarletts reading record, which inspired the new food chart (Picture: @youngmumsdiaries / Caters)

She added: ‘Kids need a push in the right direction, and I have helped Scarlett-Mai by using my imagination.

‘These days a lot of parents my age are glued to their phones and only half-heartedly help their kids with homework and reading.

‘Whereas I make sure I dedicate 30 minutes of my day to Scarlett-Mai’s reading without any distractions.

‘It has made our relationship stronger and her confidence is sky high as she is getting better and better.

‘I was told at parents evening that her reading has improved, and she has started to buckle down at school.

‘Kids love to feel appreciated and the extra half an hour reading every night means the world to her.’
